awd_titl_txt: Incorporating Tailored Hydrogen Bonding Interactions in Organic Optoelectronic Thin Films - Pursuing Universality of Form and Function
awd_abstract_narration:
Carbon-based (organic) materials hold enormous potential for use in everyday applications including displays, lighting, solar cells, transistors, and sensors.  In these contexts, it is often the three-dimensional (3-D) arrangement of the molecules in thin (10-1,000 nanometer) films that ultimately affects efficiency, stability, and overall utility. This research borrows an approach used by nature, called self-assembly, to encourage organic materials to adopt profitable arrangements in thin films largely independent of their size and shape.  Central to the universal approach of self-assembly are hydrogen bonding interactions that are also responsible for "sticking" water molecules or the DNA bases together.  In the broadest sense, the research contributes to a fundamental understanding of how to control the 3-dimensional structure of organic matter at the nano-/mesoscale to accelerate development of next-generation organic-based electronic materials.  Broader impacts with respect to education and training come from graduate and undergraduate students being exposed to multidisciplinary science that includes synthetic and physical organic chemistry, spectroscopy, computation, and materials processing/characterization.  Professors Castellano and Xue take advantage of the University of Florida (UF) Bridge to Doctorate Fellowship program, a collaboration between the Graduate School at UF and the Florida-Georgia Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (FGLSAMP), to help recruit female and minority students contribute to research and receive mentorship to encourage degree completion. Through the team's participation in U-FUTuRES, physical science content is delivered to Florida science teachers (grades 4?8).

The prevailing interactions between pi-conjugated organic molecules in thin films do not yield large energy differences among competing solid-state packing arrangements, leading to kinetically-driven spatial structures that are susceptible to minor changes to molecular structure and processing.  The structure-property studies in this research expose the thermodynamic and kinetic drivers of hydrogen bond (H-bond) guided thin film assembly to allow the charge mobility and optical characteristics to be independently addressed through rational design and synthesis.  This project specifically examines the interplay of kinetics and thermodynamics in film formation through variation of programmed intermolecular interactions and deposition conditions.  The research also introduces a bioinspired structural scan to relate H-bonding configuration to optoelectronic properties and examines alternative molecular designs involving repositioned H-bonding units within the pi-framework to improve assembly orientational control in the pi-stacking direction and with respect to the substrate.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Semiconducting, pi-conjugated organic molecules are attractive for applications spanning lighting, solar energy conversion, circuitry, and sensing. While it is known how to tailor the electronic and optical properties of individual pi-systems as well as program the arrangements of the molecules in solution, a major bottleneck for their usage is predicting and controlling three-dimensional morphological structure in solid-state thin films. The major goal of the proposed research was to use hydrogen bonded (H-bonded) assembly to guide pi-conjugated components in neat and multicomponent thin films, independent of chromophore size and shape, into profitable arrangements and allow optoelectronic properties to be programmed through rational material design at the molecular level. 

Significant intellectual merit has been generated from this award, in three general areas, and so far described in seven peer-reviewed publications (with two more in preparation). First, we further developed the ground rules for using hydrogen-bonding interactions to guide the assembly of pi-systems in optoelectronic thin films. Early work showed that installing a hydrogen-bond directing unit at the terminus of an extended pi-conjugated oligomer is both synthetically demanding and not optimal with respect to controlling molecular orientation on surfaces and in thin films. We refined our approach and pursued molecules that position an H-bonding capable unit at the molecule’s interior. The result was novel and more strongly self-associating systems that are potentially useful to maximize charge migration processes in the solid state. Additional work is required to program the orientation of these molecules on surfaces.

A second area of intellectual merit came unexpectedly, from the observation that certain pi-conjugated molecules we prepared underwent reliable isomerization in the presence of ambient laboratory light. The phenomenon is the basis for photoswitches developed from organic molecules. Using the initial discovery as a springboard, we were able to develop several new classes of photoswitching platforms, ultimately arriving at a system that shows quantitative bidirectional switching in solution and excellent photoswitching in the solid state. The final design intersects the goals of this award in that both inter- and intramolecular hydrogen bonding are central to the useful functional behavior.

A final area of significant intellectual merit concerns the development of pi-conjugated organic molecules that faithfully self-assemble in solution and the solid state much in the way that DNA and peptides do in biology. The design is very robust and relatively insensitive to molecular structure changes. Our current NSF funding plans to unite this assembly paradigm with our interest in organic optoelectronics to again control chromophore arrangements in optoelectronic thin films.

The broader impacts of the work come through the science and also human aspects. The structure-property studies in this proposal are expected to accelerate development of the next-generation of organic-based electronic materials for broad applications.  With respect to education and training, graduate and undergraduate students have been exposed to multidisciplinary science that includes synthetic and physical organic chemistry, spectroscopy, computation, materials processing/characterization, and device fabrication. This award has facilitated the training of seven graduate students and three undergraduates in chemistry, and four graduate students in materials science. The support has also allowed these individuals to present their science at various conferences, and over the lifetime of this grant nearly 35 student presentations were given. The students who have graduated have all gone on to exciting careers in academia or industry, the latter including Intel, Boeing, and Apple, etc. The PI served as lead faculty advisor of the Chemistry Club during a portion of this award and also lead organizer of the annual departmental Chemathon event; in these capacities he was able to more broadly disseminate his science with STEM teachers and students grades 6–12.


Last Modified: 12/29/2023
Modified by: Ronald K Castellano
